GA tends to be a problem when its consistently good.

I've noticed that, too. A revive passive is always incredibly strong in a game like this. Strong enough that in DotA2 the Aegis of the Immortal (their version of GA) has absolutely no stats, and only one is allowed on the field at any time. Granted, DotA2 is a bit different in its balance so that a single item not having stats isn't the end of the world even in the late-game, but it's still a very strong item to have and it can decide games. For League to allow it to be purchased by absolutely anyone, and up to all 10 people, makes it a very strong kind of item, and potentially problematic, when the balance allows for it to be.
If all 10 people have one wouldn't it be fair?

In theory, it would be. In practice, many times a lot of those champions were essentially forced into grabbing it because if they didn't then they'd be at an inherent disadvantage in Round Two because they don't want the item as much. It was part of why certain champions were picked during S2 (I believe) when GA was by far at its strongest in relation to other items: they synergized with the meta at the time, and they utilized GA well, while people who don't play nice with GA and that meta were less popular.

I'ma start off by saying I don't disagree with you, but what champions really don't synergism with GA?

If one mid lane mage, say Syndra bought it, she gives up that extra slot worth of damage, so the other Mage say Orianna wouldn't really be put at a disadvantage by buying one, and vise versa.

Burst mages don't play well against it, and neither do champions that operate best with team comboing. Orianna wouldn't be put off in theory, but in practice this means her burst pattern is less effective whereas Syndra's isn't since Orianna doesn't have GA. This also means that if a team combo comes out and kills everyone on the enemy team, the enemy team all comes back and now the team that killed them has everything on cooldown, and if they saved cooldowns for when they die the first time then you run risk of them surviving the initial burst and letting them get "extra credit" damage. This leads to both teams having to buy it when it's incredibly prevalent. It also impacts certain champions who revolve around killing and need that maintain presence or gain momentum. Karthus and Morde as examples for the former, and champions like Yi and Kat for the latter. Yi and Kat, for example, like using GA themselves but don't like when their enemies have it because it denies them resets and forces them wait before the enemy truly dies, since GA doesn't revive instantly. 

It also devalues massive burst champions like Annie and Veigar when it's strong because they typically rely on killing their target in one large burst and if they live that burst, or come back in the case of GA, then they have no more really effective killing tools against that target. 

Essentially: it adds value to champions with low cooldowns and sustained damage/support patterns (Orianna, for example, isn't a terrible pick when GA is en vogue due to her kit, her burst just becomes a bit less valuable but she has support ability to fall back on) while subtracting value from combo-based champions with larger cooldowns, and champions that maintain larger presence through enemy death (Karthus, Morde, Kat, Yi, to name some). It seems balanced and fine if you only think about it 1v1 or in smaller scales, but as soon as it becomes meta for everyone to buy it then you instantly dictate the raised or lowered value of certain picks just off that one item pick-up alone. This is part of why GA always becomes a problem when it's popular: it's a meta-warping item when it's really strong.
